Well, proof is not really what religion is about, is it? So asking where 
his proof is is kind of reduntant.
There's another reply I left on another comment thread here underneath this 
video where I go more into this but what I basically mean is that science, 
especially when it comes to these things that we can probably never turn 
into facts (but even IF we can prove these theories - which we probably 
can't - it doesn't change my point all that much), is not too far off from 
what religion is; or at least what it used to be.

Science is all about facts and proof and stuff for most, but in reality, 
once you get into the deeper things, it really is more about faith.
People theorize about things, explain matters they cannot simply observe, 
fill in the blanks with made-up stories that seem logical; what makes sense 
to them. They BELIEVE in these theories (some fully, some just think "well 
it MIGHT be true.. it's a possibility") and then the go on to test it, 
trying to mostly disprove their own theories. And if they can't, the theory 
stands for now. Then they will probably continue to believe in (the 
possibility of) them.

So believing in - or even just philosophizing about - any possible 
('scientific' or not) theory about these deeper things, really isn't too 
far off from religious territory.
And when you start talking about what we're "supposed to know" or anything 
like that, as if you were talking about fate, or some other kind of 
thing/power/entity deciding what we are to know and what not, you have 
fully entered it.

comments.text:
+Cameron Williams "you don't always have to have proof to believe in some 
things"
Of course not....if you don't care if your beliefs are true or false.
However, if you *do* care if what you believe is true or false then 
reliable evidence should be a top priority.
You're right, not everyone sees the world the same way. This does not mean 
every perception of the world is correct. I can believe as hard as i want 
that 2+2=5 or that unicorns are real but that doesn't change reality 
anywhere other than in my own mind.
By your own admission, you begin with what you choose to believe. Instead 
why not begin with attempting to reliably determining what is true and what 
is not, regardless of what you *want* to be true, and *then* conform your 
beliefs to that reality? Even then, make sure those beliefs are *tentative*...ready 
to be altered or discarded if they do not match reality. This is how 
science works.

BTW, what exactly about religion did you look at objectively which 
strengthened your faith? Lemme guess, a sick person mysteriously got better 
after someone prayed? You saw Jesus on a piece of toast? You got a warm, 
fuzzy feeling when singing a song in church?

comments.text:
that's really the problem with any theory though.
Any answer results in an endless loop of more questions.  Where do you come 
from? Your parents. Them? Their parents. And their parents. 
We go back further and further to times when our ancestors were nothing but 
single-celled organisms. Where did they come from? Where did the Earth come 
from? 
Then you get to the big bang and you ask "well, where did the stuff come 
from that made up this tightly packed matter?" and even if you could answer 
that, you'd still answer where that thing that makes up the answer comes 
from.
You will never be done. You can never answer anything fully. Not even IF we 
were somehow able to go back in time to observe what happened (which we 
aren't, so it's not unlikely that all our theories and all we think we have 
figured out is complete and utter bullshit). There's always gonna be more 
questions.

Which is actually why, to me, science really isn't too far off from 
religion when it comes to these things; and why I actually kind of have a 
problem with schools and educational TV programming teaching some of these 
theories as if they were fact, and hardcore-atheists defending these, often 
in uncivil ways, as such as well against those who refuse to believe in 
these theories or choose to believe in whatever religion they are part of 
claims.
It's really not that different. Both come up with, to the people writing 
these down, logical explanations and theories that make sense of the things 
we just cannot possibly know; because it isn't something we can look at 
with our eyes or in many ways not even something we can really calculate or 
grasp with our limited understanding of our surroundings.

Sure, to many people these days (and to me as well) it sounds absolutely 
ridiculous to say that there's some kind of god who created all this, but 
so do a lot of the theories discussed in science today. And so will 
probably a lot of the stuff that most people, including the smartest people 
in the world, seem to agree on has likely happened or is likely the 
explanation for a few things. Especially if you go into quantum physics 
territory. 
Who's really to say any of these things are even remotely true and will not 
be laughed at in like 500, 200 or even just 100 years?

People will possibly look at these books we wrote, these films we made, 
with a smile and think to themselves how stupid and naive we must've been 
to even remotely believe any of this.
Just like many do today with religious scriptures; both current and ancient.

comments.text:
Imagine a film projector.  The projector is running and shooting out moving 
images.  One can actually see the waves of  image projection flashing and 
coming out from the projector.  The flashing images inside those waves are 
made of tiny pixels (= particles.)  That is the dual nature our reality: 
waves and particles, (i.e., quantum physics.)  We are inside those waves.  
We are part of those waves.  But we are also made of tiny pixels or 
particles.  The images inside the projection waves are made of 
pixels/particles.  Does that make sense now?

What happens when you magnify the pixels that made up those images?  The 
pixels become blurry.  So.  Scientists are now trying to find out if 
particles - the building blocks of our reality - become blurry if we 
magnify into them a trillion trillion time.  (Actually, a few years ago a 
science lab accidentally discovered blurry electrons when it is doing an 
experiment for something else, now scientists are just trying to confirm 
the result again with certainty.)  If particles become blurry at a 
trillion-trillion-time magnification, then it is a good indicator that our 
reality is a huge projection.  A holographic projection.  (A real, solid 
object does not become blurry when you magnify it.)

Which would also mean that we are not really here.  We do not actually 
exist in this reality.  Our true existence is somewhere else.  We are 
really somewhere else.  Where?  Inside the roll of film or the disc inside 
the film projector.  Or some equivalence of that. 

(That's just a simplified explanation; we are a 3D projection, which means 
we are coming from more than one projectors.  It takes multiple projectors 
to create complex 3D projections.  The current hypothesis is we are being 
projected from black holes.)

includes all universes together. Which would literally be everything within 
existence, period.

Very true, the so called "simulation" hypothesis is another infinite 
regression. It's a nightmare for Ockham's razor. If we could in fact prove 
the universe is a simulation, we've simply discovered a new layer of study. 
It would still as of yet not give us any information as to what might have 
created the simulation, nor that it in fact requires sentient intervention 
to create a simulation. It might just as well be that it's another product 
of chance, just a different kind of product from what we earlier assumed.

comments.text:
+Sassy Sabrina Imagine a film projector.  It is running and projecting 
moving images.  One can actually see the waves of flashing image projection 
coming out from the projector.  The flashing images Inside those waves are 
made of tiny pixels (= particles.)  That is the dual nature our reality: 
waves and particles.  We are living inside those waves, and we are also 
made of tiny pixels or particles (when we observe anything in the waves.) 

What happens when you magnify the pixels that made up those images?  The 
pixels become blurry.  So.  Scientists are now trying to find out if 
particles - building blocks of our reality - become blurry if we magnify 
into them a trillion trillion time.  If particles become blurry at that 
magnification, then it is a good indicator that we are all living in a huge 
projection.  A holographic projection.  (A real, solid object does not 
become blurry when you magnify it.)

Which would also mean that we are not really here.  We do not actually 
exist in this reality.  Our true existence is somewhere else.  We are 
really somewhere else.  Where?  Inside the roll of film or the disc inside 
the film projector.  Or some equivalence of that.

top_comment.author: Leo Cozijn

comments.text: Well thanks, I can live with that!
comments.author: Leo Cozijn

comments.text:
+Leo Cozijn We don't know.
There is a lot that we don't know about the universe, but we are learning 
more all the time. There are different theories about what the Big Bang 
actually was, and how it occurred. The most accepted says the time began 
with the Big Bang, there was no "before" before it.
Another way of looking at your question is why did humans develop 14 
billion years after the Big Bang, and not 10 or 20 billion. Again, we don't 
know. We do know that it had to be at least a few billion years, because 
the first generation of stars needed to form and supernova in order to 
create elements like carbon and nitrogen. Life can only form on second 
generation stars.
comments.author: Eric14492

comments.text:

captions.text:
Guys… I know this is going to sound like
I'm about to get a case of the munchies…
but… what is the universe? Dude...

Hello there humble viewers, Trace here for
DNews. James Cameron said, "Science is curiosity

acted upon." Scientists all over the world,
throughout history, have attempted to answer

what is this place we're all living in! So,
with the help of Smithsonian.com, I pulled
them together in one big trippy universe explainer.

It all started with the Big Bang theory. This
theory says the universe was densely packed,

smaller than the head of a pin, and expanded
by 100 trillion trillion times in a tiny fraction

of a second. Since then, scientists figured
the universe was constantly expanding, but

didn't have direct evidence until earlier
this year when cosmologists detected ripples

in the cosmic background radiation left behind
by that event. Those ripples, if they can

be independently verified, may prove that
expansion expansion!

Assuming that is all correct, and that IS
how the universe got started, we're still
not answering WHAT THIS IS, MAN.

One theory says our universe was born in an
unstable false vacuum in spacetime. Think

of it this way, IF the universe expanded 100
trillion trillion times in a fraction of a

second, what caused it to eventually slow?
Some physicists believe it was our universe

impacting neighboring ones, like bubbles in
foam, but instead of air inside, each one

is a universe… This is called the multiverse
theory, and it COULD be proven IF they could

spot where WE are touching another universe.
Scientists looking at the light left over

from the big bang know there's an odd "cold
spot" in the sky -- perhaps that's where our

bubble is touching the neighbor's? Of course
it could also be data error... Researchers

at the University of California Santa Cruz
are looking for more evidence.

Another theory says we're living inside a
computer simulation. Basically, the paper,

written in 2002, says that if some future-race
of humans want to learn about their past,

they'll probably use their massive computer
power to simulate the entirety of their evolution,

history, and culture to observe how they came
to be. Given that so few races will ever achieve

this level of technology, we are probably
being simulated. To test this, physicists

at the University of Washington designed an
experiment to test the boundaries of this

simulation using quantum physics. Basically,
they're saying the computer is only simulating

the things it NEEDS to simulate. Like, if
a tree falls in the woods, and no one's around,

the simulation wouldn't have it make sound...
There IS a problem in quantum physics, where

particles’ locations cannot be determined
until they're observed… does this reveal
we're all a simulation?! MAYBE!! I dunno.

And recently, Ian O'Neill was here and we
talked about how the universe could be a hologram.

They're testing it right now. If we occupy
three dimensional space, and time is the fourth

dimension -- then it stands to reason that
it's made of something. Physicists crunched

the math and determined if the universe is
a hologram, then we might be "printed" on

the fabric of spacetime, and the pixels of
that printing might be detectable… They

designed an experiment and they're looking
for these pixels which are a hundred billion

billion times smaller than a proton. IS this
the truth? The scientists are looking now…

Our universe is a wondrous thing, and we're
happy to have it, obviously, but WHAT it is

and how it works is the study of some of the
greatest minds of humankind. What do YOU think?

Which of these three theories is your favorite?
What would you do if we found out one was
true?! Do you think the world would freak?

If it did, you could hear about it over on
TestTube, where Tara and I cover current events,

politics, and how these things affect YOU
and us. It's a really awesome show, I love

doing it, and I'd love it if you checked it
out. There's a link in the description OR

YOU CAN CLICK HERE?[a] to watch our video
on whether the U.S. can still call itself

a wealthy nation. If you like it, subscribe
and share it with your friends.

But, back to the universe, you've got an opinion,
and conveniently, we've got a place where

you can LEAVE your opinion. Get down there!
Come follow me on Twitter at-TraceDominguez,
and thanks for watching.
